comments.commentBody: Business model?? Look at YELP's business model. It extorts small business owners into buying ads so negative reviews get buried. Those who don't buy have negative reviews highlighted while positive reviews get buried. YELP publishes character assassination, smears, and personal attacks.

I don't understand the comparison of Facebook with Amazon. Amazon actually sells products that people want, in increasing numbers, makes money out of it, and has developed its reputation and credibility well in the process. People will continue to buy off Amazon for various reasons including discounted prices, ease of browsing through products, availability of product reviews from actual users, relative anonymity especially when it comes to purchase of certain types of products, and so on. Businesses benefit directly from Amazon because Amazon's customers are also their customers.

By contrast, what does Facebook have as its business model? The hope that people who use it may take the trouble to look at some ads and actually proceed to buy some of the stuff advertised in those ads, right?

How, did anyone imagine, was Facebook going to invest a hundred billion dollars to generate worthwhile returns? Does Zuckerberg himself have a clear plan for this? Why would anyone just hand over their cash like this, without the slightest idea how it was going to be used to generate money for them?

The obvious question for any investor to ask is: "What are you going to do with my money? Buy some diamond mines in South Africa? Invest in space exploration and bring back precious minerals or drinking water from asteroids?..."

People have bought into this offering without the slightest idea how all that money was going to be used to generate returns. That's where the problem lies.

I can't wait to see Rigoletto in Vegas... it's the only reason I would go see that "war horse" for the umteenth time...right on!!!!!

Oh, and I agree, Traviata was great.
Brava, Lori!  Exactly!

Audiences for a given opera probably self-skew.  I've seen an encouraging number of younger opera-goers--among which I count myself, though I grew up with the art and have decades of opera under my belt--at least at some performances (Nixon in China and The Makropulos Case, for instance).

New financial instruments should be tested as new aircraft are tested. They should be subjected to various market conditions, both usual and (we think) highly unlikely, to see how stable they are. If they pass the tests they would get a certificate of probable safety and their sale would be allowed.

To do such testing we would have to develop some sort of economic wind tunnel (which might also prove useful in other areas of economics and finance research). Until we had computers and the internet, there was no way to build such a wind tunnel. Now it would be fairly easy and running it would be affordable.

The decrease in government support for basic science when is just an offshoot of a mindset that can't tell the difference between consumption spending and investment. No matter what the multiplier on gov spending in terms of economic growth, nor no matter what percentage of anticipated future jobs depend on scientific competency, our current national funding climate will starve the very sources of much of our needed future growth. Combine this with Wall Street focus on short term ROI that turns most R&D from an investment to a cost, the future doesn't look too good for American Science.

This is sad for too many reasons to list.

One other thing I notice, is that the sniping amongst different branches of science isn't healthy at all. While fighting over the perceived crumbs, many in all fields choose not to do anything that would result in a larger meal. "Circle the wagons and shoot inward" is not a path to an improved future.

This comment is revealing.  It shows a real divide, and perhaps deep "conservatism," in much of the Met audience.  I found (and I'm 72) the Tosca middling, but both the Barber and, especially, the Traviata were brilliant.  The Barber is straight traditional, but the Traviata is of the best "director's opera."  An absolutely stunning, revealing production, especially on stage (the DVD is super, too).  Traditional Traviatas are "a dime a dozen," so why be so down on something that is really new (and quite faithful to Verdi, in fact) and immensely exciting to many, many opera goers.  (We can't travel; isn't it valuable to see a bit of Europe here every now and then?)

RE:  the recent Traviata and other such:   "why be so down on something that is really new?"  Because... making an extreme twist on a hugely familiar, even ubiquitous work, even however startling, revelatory, and basically successful is not something one wants to see repeatedly as the "house" production.  I found the "Big Clock" Traviata intriguing.... ONCE!  I don't want to go back repeatedly and see the same staging inhabited by all the various sopranos, tenors and baritones who REALLY are what the work is about.  "Something REALLY new?"  That would be a newly commissioned work.  Hopefully something better than merely trying to pander to the pop culture generation by entrusting the treasure trove of the Met singers, chorus, orchestra, and scene and costume shops to the likes of Rufus Wainwright.  Gelb is in WAY over his head.  As a previous poster explained to us, he really has no credentials for the job and many of my musician friends who work at the met describe him as "knowing zero about music".  REALLY?  The board thought HE was the best choice?

@ J. Kalin- "so why be so down on something that is really new?"

The fact that something is new doesn't have any bearing on its *quality*. A new production can be just as good, bad, or indifferent as a more traditional one. New productions can (and should) be judged on their merits, and whether they complement or distract from the music and story.

In addition, few of the new Met productions (e.g., Traviata) have truly been original in terms of ideas. I personally found that production cliched and gimmicky.

I completely disagree that the Traviata production was in any way faithful to Verdi. Verdi's overriding intention with that opera was REALISM (i.e., a realistic setting, realistic relationships between characters, and realistic emotions). The Decker version was completely divorced from that vision, and (in my view) disrespectful of the composer's intentions.

Hallelujah! Common sense has prevailed.

New Met productions are not always good Met productions. The Barber of Seville is brilliant, but Tosca and La Traviata are ready for the waste bin.
That's Peter Gelb.

Those who do not read reviews deprive themselves of a learning experience.  After a performance, it is always valuable to compare what a knowledgeable and articulate person, at the same performance, saw.  I read reviews to enhance my appreciation of music, dance, art.  I always look forward to hearing the gentle, intelligent voice of Lloyd Schwartz on NPR and now read him online in the Phoenix.  In the 70s I learned to love the NYCB through seeing performances and then "discussing" what I saw with reviewers in the NYTimes and the New Yorker.  Thinking and comparing points of view can be such a pleasure!
Peter Gelb

Of the 17 people that care about the Opera maybe 4 of them care about a review. And 0.3 of those care about the review in Opera news. And this is worth space and attention because? Instead it's become a judgemental evaluation of Arthur Gelb's fitness.

I'd rather see a team fighting to win, with real risk involved, than a team full of known winners and stars. I want the Yankees to put together a team full of role players and breakout players that take turns winning the games, working as a team, rather than see a team full of all-stars, trying to prove their contracts as individuals. It's just more exciting, and more relatable.
wonders if fukushima and china 50 nukes stations on hold, has any bearing on all this energy/war talk
Let's not forget that nuclear energy must be used with zero tolerance on matters of safety. So the plants that are being build must abide by the highest regulatory provisions possible.

This is something I have been saying for years. Arabs who are Islamic do want and need to be restrained either by the religion or a police state, or a mix of both. But when anyone in the non-Arab, non-Islamic west says this, they are considered prejudiced. It is obvious that most of the tenets of the Islamic religion are designed to keep women and all other minorities separated and subjugated in order to control the masses under the rule of the conservative, dictatorial males. Democracy and Islam are diametrically opposed in every single way.

Science education and basic research are so important to this country's future that cuts to these areas would probably do greater damage to the country in the long term than closing 30 or so Interstate highways for an indeterminate period, closing the more expensive national parks and keeping them in minimum maintenance mode, and best off all, cutting the Pentagon by, say, 30%. That would return the DoD to its rightful status of a defense organization with no strategic offensive capabilities.

Keep the safety net for the poor inviolable.

And return income taxes to 1960's levels! That would mean a tax increase for me, but for the good of the country I'm all for it. I'm nowhere near the 1% but I have more than I need. As it is my wife and I donate freely to education in sciences and humanities, but there is an efficiency to be gained by centralization. To argue otherwise is to lie.

Great stuff. Add to that Paul's call for aid to states to hire back teachers, policemen and firemen, and we'd be back to reasonable employment levels.

On a more fanciful level:
1) Allow the public option for health care.

2) Reverse Citizens United and Arizona Free Enterprise Club by constitutional amendment (the latter is as important as the former). Also allow for spending caps and defined limits to campaign seasons (1 month before a primary, 3 months before a general election ... and create a limited window for super pacs to air their 'free speech' say only for a month, two months before a campaign. Make lobbying a not for profit that can't be done by ex public officials.

3) Force corporations to give tenure to a majority of its employees.

4) Force corporations to give union and employee representation on its board of directors.

It's probably best that people stay home and abide by self-imposed curfews while things cool down. The crime wave should be reported on as generously as possible, how else can the government and municipalities know what strength must be deployed in the police force? What's the matter with their police? The anarchy on the streets is ugly and while some egyptians in the diaspora may want to here only about the tourism and the beauty and attractiveness of Egypt, not wanting the world to know that Eygpt has violent thugs like everywhere else, who are for now less suppressed than elsewhere perhaps. But most benefit most by knowing how many rapes, assaults, murders, and other such statistics in plain language.
Mr. Silver forgets that Iran threatens Israel with annihilation. Israel does not threaten anyone.
It's almost as if people are being payed by Big Money to look for reasons not to do anything and to avoid looking at the facts.
@ coffic - No, I would not shoot a neighbor first just because I felt threatened; that would constitute murder.

Reply to ajroud -

Instead of accepting the territorial compromise the UN recommneded in 1947, Arab leaders launched a war to seize the whole territory. They refused to recognize that Jews had any rights to the land, refused any compromises that would allow both peoples to fulfill their national aspirations, and refused to accept the existence of a Jewish state. Tthe 1947 UN Partition Plan offered historic justice to the Jewish people and to Palestinian Arabs, who were given the opportunity to create the first Palestinian Arab state in history.

In 1967, Arab aggression led to another war of self-defense in which Israel captured more territory. The Israeli government immediately offered to return the territory in exchange for peace. Jordan refused to take back the West Bank in exchange for peace (although Jordan and Israel ultimately signed a peace treaty in 1994). In 1979-82 Israel did return territory- the Sinai - to Egypt as part of a peace treaty brokered by the US.

Israel has not sought to enlarge its territory by attacking others. Its boundaries have changed only as a result of wars initiated against Israel by its Arab neighbors.

Full civil and political rights, including the right to vote, extend to all of Israel's citizens, including its almost one million Arabs citizens. Arabs have been elected to, and serve in, the Israeli legislature, the Knesset, and even sit on the Israeli Supreme Court.

Eugene Gorrin –
1- While Arab aggression may have precipitated the 1967 War, it does not give Israel the right to continue its occupation of those lands 45 years after the war. Numerous UN Resolutions call for its move back to the 1967 borders.
2- As regards the rights of its Arab citizens, you don’t mention they can only walk on certain sides of certain streets, are required to have special license plates on their cars (repulsively reminiscent of Jews being forced to wear yellow stars on their arms). That recently passed laws order the withdrawal of government funding to any organization or institution marking Israel’s Independence Day as an occasion for mourning (which it is for Arabs who have lost their lands); allow communities smaller than 400 households to refuse to accept new residents on the basis of race, faith, and other collective identifications; allows any settler who claims economic injury (even if without proof) from a call to boycott Jewish settlement produce to sue the organizers of the boycott for damages. Beacon of democracy indeed.

This is 1940 all over again. The sanction process will prove to be the equivalent of Neville Chamberlain's appeasement of Hitler.

Does anyone truly believe that Iran's leaders will open all their nuclear development facilities - most importantly those which are hidden underground and not yet detected by intelligence - to inspections and cease their enrichment of uranium? With the Nuremberg laws of the 1930s and Mein Kampf, Hitler made clear what would become of European Jews.

Iran's influential rulers and clerics directly call for Iran to use nuclear weapons against Israel with the goal of annihilating Israel and another generation of Jewish people.

As in 1940, the world remains silent. The so-called sanctions and meetings will prevent nothing. Israel is not a perfect nation, but is any? In spite of how you may feel about some of Israel's policies, Israel has been a blessing to the world with its scientific and agricultural achievements, which it freely shares for the good of other nations. It works closely with many poor African nations to help address their needs for water and healthy crops. Israelis are first to volunteer as first responders for emergencies around the world. Medical teams travel around the world to help those who lack health care.

How can we remain silent? How can we allow our ally to remain under such a threat?

Not surprising. As someone who's made, and followed up on, feature requests for Chrome and Calendar, I've encountered those developers' apparent contempt for their users. To say nothing of a recent Google shopping search returning a scam storefront as one of the top results.
you assume a level of technical sophistication beyond the average householder.  and you place the onus on the victim, rather than the perpetrator.
MOst users rely on "plug and play" and dont even know what SSID is - they should have some level of privacy protection as well

If you are running a wireless network you shouldn't be broadcasting the SSID. Once you do that the network is not visible to random scanning.

I've been wireless for more than 15 years with no hacking issues.

We go to New York City five times a year for two to three week periods each time. We see plays on and off Broadway, gallery openings, ballet, and opera at The Met, all depending on the season and availability. We see what we can based on what's being offered when we are in Manhattan. We enjoy eating at new restaurants.

Our biggest disappointment over the past two years has been with productions at the Metropolitan Opera. It has lost its way. I agree with comments about "grand opera" no longer being grand at The Met. There is an arrogance at work involving leadership. The demand to censor reviews was appalling. It's part of the "how dare you criticize me, I'm perfect" school of bureaucracy.

Mr. Gelb did not write any of the operas he's desecrating. He seems to want to leave some kind of legacy without having written a note. It really is time to let the great opera classics stand on their own merit. He has not improved one single opera with his meddling. The operas we don't see in NYC, we see in movie theaters live via digital presentation.

The sadness here is that we have become less and less interested in seeing opera at The Met or via digital showings. This is because of one man's interference with greatness. Gelb needs to go. And sooner rather than later.
While the crime occured in the United States and the victim was American, the accused--and now convicted--individual is an Indian citizen who risked deportation if convicted.

I was also bothered by Dolan's condesdending and overly chummy attitude towards the anchors. He didn't do his position any good. If contraception has the support of an overwhelming majority, how can the government not mandate its inclusion in the healthcare law?

Plus, did you notice how Charlie and Erica didn't really ask pertinent, newsworthy questions? Perhaps they could have asked, "What about the Constitutional rights of the employees at Catholic hospitals and schools?" or "Isn't the Constitution for individuals and not churches?"

The church's "rights" violated? I don't think so!

Dolan like Scalia, Cheney, Rove, Demint, and so many others is a hypocrite and a fool. One and all they think whatever they feel with no regard for intellectual integrity. And you can just forget about issues of morality and ethics. Dead end logic, cherry picked arguments, and false equivalency are the arrows in the religionist quiver.

How the church justifies interceding in employes healthcare decision but has nothing substantive to say on so many other real questions we as a society are struggling with belies its real motives. Just grubby little men grasping for power.

I watched Dolan perform on CBS This Morning, getting all chummy and familiar with the anchors with "you know, Charlie," and "as you know, Erica." I thought to myself, what a pompous smug! Hardly fitting for a man of te clothe, I know. But, we shall know them by their fruit, Jesus said.

Well done, Ms Dowd.

I saw the current and prior Ring (except for Rheingold), and loved nearly every moment of both. The only thing I objected to was the silly exploding-head statues at the end of Gotterdammerung. For all its noise, the Lepage set struck me as brilliant and positive in supporting the music and drama, producing some colorful and interesting effects. The singing was spectacular, and the orchestral playing excellent. But I understand the criticisms, and am glad ON will continue to publish them.

I'm going to guess that he was also limited by not having cleaned up his interior issues sufficiently before he began these spiritual experiences -- a lot of what we understand are shadows produced by our own fears and desires, and some stuff thought to be a spiritual experience is merely glimpsing, I think, what we might call the future.
Indian railways need to be privatized, or allow competition in, like Indian Airways had to.
